revised_title: Antigen-Induced Secretion in the Optic Gland of Octopus vulgaris: A Hormonal Defense Mechanism
tldr: The optic gland of Octopus vulgaris responds to foreign proteins by producing and releasing a particulate material. This material, which may be identical to the optic gland hormone, is not membrane-bound and has a size of about 30 nm. The hormone is involved in a defense mechanism against non-octopus proteins and may cause death in cephalopods to limit population growth.
scientific_discipline: Biology and Life Sciences > Neurobiology and Endocrinology
